user_request: A romantic poem about two hearts beating as one.

revision_history.draft:
Gears mesh in the dark, their teeth a silent Morse code  
Each gear a stubborn orbit, each spring a coiled confession  
The moon’s pull on tides, a gravitational whisper—no touch, just alignment  
Metronomes blink in their cages, ticks carving time into dust  
They spin, yet no two rhythms share the same fracture  
A clockwork hymn, where every part is both a thread and a blade

Gears mesh in the dark, their teeth a silent Morse code  
Each gear a relentless orbit, each spring a coiled confession  
The moon’s pull on tides, a gravitational sigh—no touch, just alignment  
Metronomes pulse in their cages, ticks carving time into dust  
They spin, yet no two rhythms share the same split  
A clockwork dirge, where every part is both a thread and a blade

Gears mesh in the dark, their jagged teeth a silent Morse code  
Each gear a relentless orbit, each spring a coiled confession  
The moon’s pull on tides, a gravitational sigh—no touch, just alignment  
Metronomes pulse in their cages, ticks sculpting time into dust  
They spin, yet no two rhythms share the same fraction  
A clockwork dirge, where every part is both a thread and a dagger

final_poem:
Gears mesh in the dark, their jagged teeth a silent Morse  
Each gear a relentless orbit, each spring a coiled confession  
The moon’s pull on tides, a gravitational sigh—no touch, just alignment  
Metronomes pulse in their cages, ticks carve time into dust  
They spin, yet no two rhythms share the same fractional measure  
A clockwork dirge, where every part is both a thread and a dagger
